byline.contributor: Alan Blinder reported from Ashland, Ky., and Tamar Lewin from New York. Peter Baker and Sheryl Gay Stolberg contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and TAMAR LEWIN

abstract: County Clerk Kim Davis of Rowan County, Ky, is jailed for contempt of court after defying federal court order to issue licenses to same-gender couples; within hours of ruling to detain Davis, who is an elected government official, some Republican presidential candidates jump into fray to support her, indication that case is turning into increasingly charged political cause for Christian conservatives across nation.
lead_paragraph: Kim Davis of Rowan County rejected a proposal that would have allowed her deputies to grant same-sex marriage licenses. Had she consented, a federal judge would have considered releasing her from jail.

headline.main: Clerk in Kentucky Chooses Jail Over Deal on Same-Sex Marriage
headline.print_headline: Clerk Chooses Jail Over Deal on Gay Unions

snippet: Kim Davis of Rowan County rejected a proposal that would have allowed her deputies to grant same-sex marriage licenses. Had she consented, a federal judge would have considered releasing her from jail.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject
